headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Carnival Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Howard Frank, Vice Chairman and Chief Operating Officer. P
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Carnival Corporation First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Howard Frank, Vice Chairman and Chief Operating Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. This is Howard Frank. With me this morning is Micky Arison, our Chairman and CEO; Beth Roberts, our Vice President of Investor Relations; and David Bernstein, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. We're going to co
componenttext: Good morning, everyone. This is Howard Frank. With me this morning is Micky Arison, our Chairman and CEO; Beth Roberts, our Vice President of Investor Relations; and David Bernstein, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. We're going to continue our normal presentation this morning and I'm going to have David take you through the first quarter color and some details.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Before I begin, please note that some of the remarks on this conference call will be forward-looking. I will refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release. Also all of my references to revenue and costs will be in local
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Before I begin, please note that some of the remarks on this conference call will be forward-looking. I will refer you to the cautionary statement in today's press release. Also all of my references to revenue and costs will be in local currency unless otherwise noted as this is a much better indicator of business trend. 
For the first quarter, our earnings per share were $0.19. The first quarter came in at the high end of our December guidance, which was $0.15 to $0.19 per share. The $0.02 per share improvement versus the midpoint of our December guidance was driven primarily by $0.04 of favorability in a variety of cost areas, partially offset by higher-than-expected fuel prices which caused an additional $0.02. 
Now let's look at our first quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased 5% for the first quarter with substantially all of the increase coming from our European, Australian and Asian brand or as we call them, our EAA brand. Our EAA brands grew 11% while our North American brands grew 2%. 
Our net revenue yields increased 2% in the first quarter, driven by a net ticket yield increase of 3%. Our EAA brands were up 9% as a result of yield improvements in South America. The South America market has rebounded nicely from last year's challenging season which was impacted by significant increases in industry capacity. 
Our North American brands were down 1% driven by lower yields in the Caribbean due to the higher industry capacity, which we discussed in the last conference call, and is limited to winter deployment. In net onboard and other yields, we experienced a 1% decline. The decrease resulted from favorable items we recognized in the first quarter of last year related to minimum guarantee payments for calendar year 2009 and a litigation settlement. We mentioned these items during the first quarter conference call last year. 
If we normalized the prior year for these items, net onboard and other yields for the first quarter would have been up 3%. On the cost side, net cruise cost excluding fuel for available lower berth day were up 3% versus the prior year. However, if you exclude the gain on the sale of P&O Cruises Artemis, which reduced net cruise cost last year by $44 million, the net cruise cost excluding fuel per ALBD would have been in line with the prior year. 
Fuel prices this quarter were up 9% and that cost us about $0.05 per share. In summary, we were pleased with the first quarter EPS of $0.19, which is up from last year's adjusted EPS of $0.12 before the favorable impact of $0.10 of unusual items. 
Now turning to our 2011 outlook. I will skip the full year outlook. I'll skip the revenue yields as Howard will discuss that shortly. On the cost side, for the full year come net cruise cost excluding fuel per ALBD are forecasted to be flat to up 1%. This guidance is about 0.5 percentage point than we forecasted in December. We are seeing some more inflationary pressures than we thought in crew travel, food cost, freight and other areas. Most of these items were simply a function of rising fuel and commodity prices. However, our current guidance for interest expense, taxes and depreciation is lower, which balances out the additional inflationary pressures. 
One final note I wanted to share with you our current rules of thumb about the impact that current fuel prices and currency can have on our results. To start with, a 10% change in the price of fuel for the remaining three quarters of 2011 represents a $0.22 per share impact. With respect to FX movement, a 10% change in all currencies relative to the U.S. dollar but also for the remaining three quarters of 2011 would also impact our P&L by $0.22 per share. 
At this point, I will turn the call back to Howard.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. Taking a look at the overall booking picture for the remainder of 2011. The fleetwide basis, occupancies are slightly lower than a year ago on a 5% increase in cruise capacity for the next three quarters. Ticket pricing for these booking
componenttext:
Thank you, David. Taking a look at the overall booking picture for the remainder of 2011. The fleetwide basis, occupancies are slightly lower than a year ago on a 5% increase in cruise capacity for the next three quarters. Ticket pricing for these bookings are nicely higher than last year. 
Looking at this picture by major markets, north American occupancy is slightly behind last year with a nicely higher pricing. Bookings for Europe, Asia, Australia or EAA are also slightly behind last year and higher prices. So that is a snapshot of the fleetwide bookings that as we reconciled in 2011 as it stands today. 
Turning to booking patterns since at the start of the year on a fleetwide basis, bookings have been running higher year-over-year at higher prices. In North America, weighed bookings have paced the increase in North American capacity with solid increases in year-over-year pricing. 
In EAA, bookings have also been higher during this way period at approximately the same year-over-year prices but the booking pace has lagged the 8.6% capacity increase for the period. EAA bookings and pricing during this period have been affected by the recent disruptions in the European brands, the Middle East and North African itineraries for the remainder of the year. The result of political unrest in that area of the world, it was a significant slowdown and demand for these itineraries with related effect on booking volumes and pricing. Over 280 cruises have been to be reset and we estimate the cost of this disruption to our business will be approximately $44 million of lost revenue or about a nickel a share for the year. 
So summarizing the booking pattern during the way season so far, demand for our cruises continues to be strong. At this time, stronger in North America than in the EAA markets. The EAA brand in particular, Costa and Ibero Cruises have felt the effects of the political unrest in the Middle East and North Africa and the related disruptions to the itineraries which are related to these countries. 
In terms of our revised guidance for 2011, the effect of the increase in fuel prices has cost us $355 million or $0.45 per share. Currency exchange rates have benefited us by $0.09 per share. Cost of disruptions in the itineraries which call in the Middle East and North Africa is approximately a nickel a share. These factors have cost us to take our earnings guidance down for 2011 to a range of $2.55 to $2.65 a share or midpoint of $2.60. 
Now some color on each of the course. Fleetwide capacity in the second quarter of 2011 will be 5% higher, 2.9% in North America, France and 8.6% for EAA brands. On a fleetwide basis, occupancies are at approximately the same levels as last year and local currency pricing is higher than a year ago. 
At this juncture, we only have a small amount of inventory left to sell in the second quarter. North American brands are 55% in the Caribbean with the balance in various other itineraries. Currently, pricing for North American brands in the second quarter is higher than a year ago with occupancies at the same level. Caribbean pricing has shown improvement from the first quarter and is down only slightly from last year's second quarter Caribbean prices. Pricing for the various other North American brand itineraries, including shoulder Alaska and Europe seasons and most other itineraries is higher than a year ago. 
For EAA brands, they are 54%. In European itineraries, up slightly from a year ago with the balance in various other itineraries. Local currency ticket pricing for EAA brand cruises in Europe is slightly higher than a year ago. Pricing for EAA brands varies other itineraries taken together is also slightly higher than last year. 
From an overall standpoint to summarize the second quarter, we are forecasting the fleetwide local currency revenue yields will be higher for both North America and EAA brands, booking momentum and pricing particularly for EAA brands slowed somewhat during the way season as a result of the political unrest as I have previously discussed, notwithstanding the voyage disruption resulted from the political unrest. We are forecasting European brand yields to be higher than a year ago but not as high as we originally expected. 
Second quarter guidance is affected as following: Fleetwide revenue yields on a local currency basis for the second quarter are now expected to be 1.5% to 2.5% higher than a year ago, this is slightly lower than our early expectations as the result of the itinerary disruptions I previously referred to. Fuel price increases are expected to result in $140 million or $0.18 per share of higher fuel cost compared to the second quarter of 2010.  Costs other than fuel are forecasted to be higher in the 2% to 3% range for the quarter due to a variety of factors, some of which David previously discussed and described in the first quarter. Taken all these factors together, the second quarter 2011 earnings guidance will be in a range of $0.24, down from $0.32 per share in the second quarter of 2010. 
Now turning to the third quarter. Capacity on third quarter is expected to increase by 4.8% to 3.4% in North America and 7.2% for EAA brands. Third quarter booking patterns are progressing quite well with fleetwide pricing well ahead of last year at lower occupancies. North American brand capacity for the third quarter was 36% in the Caribbean, down slightly from 41% last year. 25% in Europe, an increase from 17% last year, which is almost an 50% increase or about 50%. And 24% in Alaska, which is about the same as last year. Pricing for all North American brand itineraries in the third quarter is well ahead of last year with particularly higher occupancy and pricing in this year's Alaska season. Pricing for North American brands in Europe is also ahead of last year and lower occupancies, which is not surprising given the approximate increase in European capacity for our North American brands in the summer. 
Caribbean pricing for the third quarter is higher than a year ago, also on lower occupancies. This is a refreshing change for our Caribbean program given the challenge ahead during the first and second quarter. 
For EAA, brand capacity is 88% in European itineraries. The EAA pricing is nicely ahead of last year and slightly lower occupancies notwithstanding the challenges resulting from the political unrest in the Middle East and Western Africa. As mentioned earlier, the EAA bookings in the last five to six weeks have been challenging as some booking momentum lost as a result of the itinerary issues in this region of the world. Now that itineraries for these cruises have been reestablished and are in the marketplace, we believe the booking momentum will start to pick up again. 
On overall basis, we are forecasting fleetwide pricing for the third quarter to be up nicely for both North America and EAA business segments. For the fourth quarter, on a fleetwide basis, capacity is up 5.9%, 3.3% for North America brands and 10.1% for EAA brands. Pricing on a fleetwide basis is nicely higher year-over-year with a similar pattern to the third quarter occupancies are lower than last year, which is also consistent with the pattern that we are experiencing in the third quarter. 
Fourth quarter booking picture is encouraging but it's early in the booking cycle, so I caution not to read too much into the fourth quarter booking picture at this time. North American brands are 42% and the Caribbean down from 50% last year. 14% in Europe 9% up from 9% last year. And 10% in Orient and Pacific cruises, which is about the same as last year. 
Pricing across North American brand itineraries is running higher than last year and slightly higher occupancies across the fleet. EAA brands of 72% in Europe up from 65% last year with the balance in various other itineraries. Pricing for European cruises is nicely higher year-over-year with pricing for the various other itineraries taken together also higher on a year-over-year basis. 
Occupancies are lower for European itineraries, which is not surprising given the 20% increase in European brand employment for the fourth quarter. It's still early to have a more precise picture for fleetwide fourth quarter pricing on. A fleetwide basis we are currently forecasting local currency revenue yields will be nicely higher in the fourth quarter. 
And so that kind of summarizes what the yield outlook for the remainder of the year look like at the current time. And with that, I'll turn it back to Kyle, I'll turn call back to you for questions for the people of the call then.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Janet Brashear with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Janet Brashear with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you can talk a little bit about the commission structure that you are debuting in the U.K. and to the extent that the purpose is to get a little bit of control back over pricing and discounting and things like that, can you talk about why that
componenttext: I wonder if you can talk a little bit about the commission structure that you are debuting in the U.K. and to the extent that the purpose is to get a little bit of control back over pricing and discounting and things like that, can you talk about why that wouldn't work in the U.S. as well?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The U.K. policy has been put together by the U.K. brands to compensate for the heavy rebidding that have become institutionalized in the U.K. and that the belief was with lower pricing by the brands and the lower commission level, they could turn the tide
componenttext: The U.K. policy has been put together by the U.K. brands to compensate for the heavy rebidding that have become institutionalized in the U.K. and that the belief was with lower pricing by the brands and the lower commission level, they could turn the tide of the rebidding. It's something that I think is not an issue in the U.S. the way it used to be and has been dealt out with in the U.S. in different ways. So I think you have to look at the U.K. as a unique market where the brands felt that they have to get a good control of their pricing and took this kind of action. I think in the long run, they believe and I think the major retail travel agents that they've negotiated and talked to believe, that this will be in the best interest of everybody. But we shouldn't look beyond the U.K., it's not a model that we will be looking at anywhere else

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you also talk just a little bit more about the charges in the Middle East and North America relative to what markets you had to pull itineraries out of and maybe where you are putting those ships in new itineraries?
componenttext: Could you also talk just a little bit more about the charges in the Middle East and North America relative to what markets you had to pull itineraries out of and maybe where you are putting those ships in new itineraries?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean that we will out just the whole North African stops in Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt and we pulled out, actually, in some cases, we got to pull out of Israel because we got a lot of resistance. We haven't done in all cases. But people are just concern
componenttext: I mean that we will out just the whole North African stops in Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt and we pulled out, actually, in some cases, we got to pull out of Israel because we got a lot of resistance. We haven't done in all cases. But people are just concerned about going to that part of the world and we've kind of, I don't know all the details in the 280 different cruises that we redone. But a lot of the calls are now call going into that part of the Eastern Mediterranean but there are only two ports in Turkey and perhaps Cypress and the Greek islands and things along those lines

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: What I just said was primarily the European brands primarily Costa and Iberocruceros. The reaction of the North American brands have been more muted and they have a lot less calls in those countries as well. Canceling Tunisia was a relatively small change
componenttext: What I just said was primarily the European brands primarily Costa and Iberocruceros. The reaction of the North American brands have been more muted and they have a lot less calls in those countries as well. Canceling Tunisia was a relatively small change in the itineraries. But canceling, obviously canceling Egypt and some other areas near Egypt created total itinerary changes, again primarily for Costa and Iberocruceros. It didn't affected North America anywhere near as much as it affected Europe.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk a little bit about what the customer reaction to these itinerary changes? It seems like they're just going back because they didn't know what your itinerary was going to be but now that the itineraries have been set, you should be able t
componenttext: Can you just talk a little bit about what the customer reaction to these itinerary changes? It seems like they're just going back because they didn't know what your itinerary was going to be but now that the itineraries have been set, you should be able to be more effectively sell them. Is that the impression that you're getting to? And then secondly, the pricing seems to be very good, seems to continue to be very good, although you mentioned a couple times that your occupancy might be a little lower. Is it just a strategic move given the pent-up demand for travel amongst consumers that you're better off holding these prices here and then filling them in as you get closer to booking?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think on the changes for the Middle East itineraries, I think there's too much noise right now for us to tell. It's obviously as itineraries change, passengers decide where they want to go on the new itinerary or not or want to change their mind and go
componenttext: I think on the changes for the Middle East itineraries, I think there's too much noise right now for us to tell. It's obviously as itineraries change, passengers decide where they want to go on the new itinerary or not or want to change their mind and go to a different itinerary. And so there's a lot of booking canceling going on so it's very hard to really judge exactly the total impact. But we're hopeful that once now that all the itineraries are out there and people understand it, that will settle down and we'll go back to a normal booking pattern. As far as rising for the summer, yes. I think because we've been able to achieve higher prices, we have been holding out for those higher prices and that's what you are seeing a little bit lower occupancies to compensate for those higher prices, but that's versus last year. We obviously fell last year and the feeling is that we can hold out for the pricing hopefully for this year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: One final quick question, which is dividend, share buyback, cash flows are going to be significant over the last couple years. Can you give us your latest thoughts dollars acknowledging that you just raise your dividend just a few months ago?
componenttext: One final quick question, which is dividend, share buyback, cash flows are going to be significant over the last couple years. Can you give us your latest thoughts dollars acknowledging that you just raise your dividend just a few months ago?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, you're right. We do anticipate good cash flows over the next couple of years. For 2011, we expect to have free cash flow of about $1 billion. And given that we raised the dividend in January the dividend in this year will be $700 million. So th
componenttext: Yes, well, you're right. We do anticipate good cash flows over the next couple of years. For 2011, we expect to have free cash flow of about $1 billion. And given that we raised the dividend in January the dividend in this year will be $700 million. So there isn't that much significant extra cash flow this year, only $300 million. And going forward in '12 and beyond as I said before, it is a board decision. And as we move forward, we will discuss that with the board whether it be share buybacks or dividend or anything else.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Felicia Hendrix with Barclays Capital.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: So in Micky, I'll direct this one to you, in this fuel environment, have you been rethinking that fuel hedging philosophy at all as company?
componenttext: So in Micky, I'll direct this one to you, in this fuel environment, have you been rethinking that fuel hedging philosophy at all as company?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll refer that one to Howard.
componenttext: I'll refer that one to Howard.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we've had discussions about and what we decided to do is take another fresh look at hedging strategies and whether we really think it makes sense for the business on a long-term basis with a real long-term benefits for the business. There is a
componenttext: Obviously, we've had discussions about and what we decided to do is take another fresh look at hedging strategies and whether we really think it makes sense for the business on a long-term basis with a real long-term benefits for the business. There is a cost associated with doing an accounting hedge type of program of some consequence. The cost, we'd like to avoid. Nonetheless we kind of huddle and decided let's take a look at it again just to see things whether our views have changed and whether there are other factors, which should just we should change.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you are in the process of doing that now?
componenttext: So you are in the process of doing that now?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: We are starting over that now right after this conference call. We've had a discussion. We're doing, it's quite a bit of work. So we've asked our department to go ahead and start to gather data and look at empirical evidence and forward-looking fuel curve
componenttext: We are starting over that now right after this conference call. We've had a discussion. We're doing, it's quite a bit of work. So we've asked our department to go ahead and start to gather data and look at empirical evidence and forward-looking fuel curves and see whether anything makes sense for us.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I will add that this is not the first review. We've done this many times and the conclusions that we came to. So I wouldn't prejudge what conclusions we will come to, again, but you shouldn't take for granted that we haven't done this many times.
componenttext: I will add that this is not the first review. We've done this many times and the conclusions that we came to. So I wouldn't prejudge what conclusions we will come to, again, but you shouldn't take for granted that we haven't done this many times.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then Howard, so you gave us a lot of color about how the political unrest in the Middle East is affecting the momentum in the EAA business. Wondering if is there anything in the EAA itineraries that aren't in that region? Maybe you could just give bec
componenttext: And then Howard, so you gave us a lot of color about how the political unrest in the Middle East is affecting the momentum in the EAA business. Wondering if is there anything in the EAA itineraries that aren't in that region? Maybe you could just give because I thought you said that 54% of the capacity was actually in your, but I don't know if you're including that as an itinerary, so I'm just wondering if you are seeing a slowing in momentum in the EAA brand for the non-Middle Eastern part of itinerary? And then similarly, I'm just wondering what the momentum has been on the North America demand for Europe? And then have you seen any change in demand trends for the North American consumer in general?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the EAA cruises, a lot of those itineraries get are either one, in some cases, may be two calls in the Mediterranean ports and then they go for the South to North African ports. We haven't been able to, there's so much noise in the booking pattern
componenttext: Yes, on the EAA cruises, a lot of those itineraries get are either one, in some cases, may be two calls in the Mediterranean ports and then they go for the South to North African ports. We haven't been able to, there's so much noise in the booking patterns for these brands right now for their Mediterranean and Eastern Mediterranean cruises. And we haven't dissected the information in a way that what didn't call there, what did call there and how are the bookings for those particular itineraries that didn't call there. We really didn't haven't done that work. But our view is that a large part of what we are seeing is relating to that kind of noise I I'm also think, I can't speak  to the European consumer, but in places like Libya and Egypt and Tunisia, are a lot closer to Southern Europe. And I think perhaps in the minds of European, it maybe some caution on what we're doing but I don't think very much of that but I think there may be something in there but we haven't really done the work to know, to be honest with you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And what about the momentum for the North American consumer? Have you seen a change at all?
componenttext: And what about the momentum for the North American consumer? Have you seen a change at all?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, demand in North America has been pretty solid since way season, both for Europeans cruises, Alaskan cruises and other kinds of itineraries. So the demand seems to be pretty solid. I would say if you look at it from premium brands versus contemporary b
componenttext: No, demand in North America has been pretty solid since way season, both for Europeans cruises, Alaskan cruises and other kinds of itineraries. So the demand seems to be pretty solid. I would say if you look at it from premium brands versus contemporary brands, we are seeing I think pretty good strength in those premium brands where for longer cruises, European programs, Alaskan programs. And for Caribbean programs, it's good. But I think we'll see a lot of the yield improvement that we are expecting to come from those areas where we received good historical demand for those types of cruises from the North American market.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay because there's just some concern how higher fuel costs are affecting the North American consumer to airline ticket prices could be affecting the demand, you're not seeing that?
componenttext: Okay because there's just some concern how higher fuel costs are affecting the North American consumer to airline ticket prices could be affecting the demand, you're not seeing that?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we do hear about the high ticket prices. But and you know, it could be that the strong Alaska season, it's really quite strong. Maybe people saying, well, instead of going to Europe, let's go to Alaska because the air cost is low. But really, we don
componenttext: Well, we do hear about the high ticket prices. But and you know, it could be that the strong Alaska season, it's really quite strong. Maybe people saying, well, instead of going to Europe, let's go to Alaska because the air cost is low. But really, we don't know that. All we know is European business is good. Now we'll be running behind in occupancies that we have this huge increase in capacity in Europe. And our competitors have huge capacity increase, our North American competitors have had huge increase capacity in the Europe. But the absolute numbers of bookings are quite good for Europe.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the capacity is not to think, it's capacity so we still very bullish on this summer in both Europe and Alaska.
componenttext: And the capacity is not to think, it's capacity so we still very bullish on this summer in both Europe and Alaska.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Lyall with John W. Bristol.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Lyall with John W. Bristol.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I believe it David said that you got offsets in lower D&A taxes and interest expense for the year. Could you walk through why that is?
componenttext: So I believe it David said that you got offsets in lower D&A taxes and interest expense for the year. Could you walk through why that is?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is again, versus our December guidance and ferns tons in D&A, some of the brands were a little bit aggressive about when they would put some of those maintenance CapEx items into service. And so we saw some favorability in the first quarter and
componenttext: Sure. This is again, versus our December guidance and ferns tons in D&A, some of the brands were a little bit aggressive about when they would put some of those maintenance CapEx items into service. And so we saw some favorability in the first quarter and we reevaluated that and we flow that through for the year. It's just the timing of when things is going to service. As far as of interest expense is concerned, again, we saw favorability in the first quarter and we flow that into more through the year. For things like we went back to a few banks, we ask them to lower the interest rate on some of our loans because quite honestly, margins have come in over the last year or so. We're using the CP margin more aggressively, which is cheaper than our revolver and so we took that in. And we also reevaluated our income taxes. We had a pretty substantial increase in our income tax expense from 2010 to 2011 in our December guidance. And now, that we got a little bit more experienced during the first quarter and have a better picture in the year, we just evaluated that. We took it down but we still are up versus the prior year in terms of income taxes. So all of that as I said before kind of offset some of the inflationary pressures in cruise cost.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. A couple of I guess itinerary questions. Are you seeing stronger demand in Alaska and maybe Northern Europe as a result of the dislocations in Northern Africa? And then kind of a related question, Caribbean improving for the first time in
componenttext: That's helpful. A couple of I guess itinerary questions. Are you seeing stronger demand in Alaska and maybe Northern Europe as a result of the dislocations in Northern Africa? And then kind of a related question, Caribbean improving for the first time in really quite some time, do you really think you are trying to corner there in terms of supply and demand?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, your comments on Alaska. Alaska has been strong already for a while for this year, prior. I think I can say, bookings were strong well before the issues in the Middle East came up. So while the situation uncertainty on the Middle East put in effect
componenttext: First, your comments on Alaska. Alaska has been strong already for a while for this year, prior. I think I can say, bookings were strong well before the issues in the Middle East came up. So while the situation uncertainty on the Middle East put in effect helped Alaska, I think the trend was in place well before. So I don't, it's not one created the issue for the other. I think Alaska based on the agreements we reached with the governor last year, lower head taxes and much higher marketing spend by the Alaska, the state of Alaska has really helped plus obviously capacity versus the. So the Combination of those things I think really helped Alaska. So Northern Europe I think we're doing well but I don't think it's any different than the rest of Europe.

componenttext: I think we're doing well in Northern Europe. I don't know that we know, it's hard to know why. We don't do any polling on it or what our customers are thinking but we know they're bookings, we know the booking is going well.

When you talk about the slowdown that you've seen in recent weeks, would you say in particularly the EAA brands, would you say that, that is sort of continuing to deteriorate or has that fairly stabilized now, in other words, versus what it might have been for two weeks ago?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The problem with answering the question is that what happens when you change like 200 itineraries is you have a lot of people changing that. I'm referring to primarily Costa and Ibero, so I don't think this is a global issue. We get a lot of churn. So we
componenttext: The problem with answering the question is that what happens when you change like 200 itineraries is you have a lot of people changing that. I'm referring to primarily Costa and Ibero, so I don't think this is a global issue. We get a lot of churn. So we got a lot more books but they're coming off people who change their mind and cancel one itinerary to get on another itinerary. So it creates a difficult, until it settles down, it is difficult to gauge what's going on. I can say this much is historically, we found that European believe their vacations are very important to them. And if they had chosen to take a cruise to the Holy Land and have now canceled because of these issues, we believe that eventually, that will get rebooked on Costa and Iberocruceros if they are from places like Italy, France and Spain because these people will take their vacation. So right now, there's a lot of churn going on. It's difficult to tell exactly what the bottom line effect. We tried to estimate it, we estimated it at $44 million, we'll see. But for the next few weeks because these itineraries can change, it's only Monday.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the sequential increase from the first quarter to the second quarter in your cost. And I'm trying to get a sense of whether or not the rebooking costs are really driving most of that increase? Because it would appe
componenttext: I wanted to dig a little bit deeper into the sequential increase from the first quarter to the second quarter in your cost. And I'm trying to get a sense of whether or not the rebooking costs are really driving most of that increase? Because it would appear that for the balance of the year, the cost increase aren't quite as severe.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, when you take a look overall at the cost structure, we talked about cost being flat to up 1% for the year. But keep in mind that it does vary by quarter, there are seasonality differences. Advertising is a great example of seasonality differences. An
componenttext: Yes, when you take a look overall at the cost structure, we talked about cost being flat to up 1% for the year. But keep in mind that it does vary by quarter, there are seasonality differences. Advertising is a great example of seasonality differences. And one of the reasons why the second quarter is a bit higher to is because they are projecting perhaps some more advertising expense over and above last year. And there are other things in repair and maintenance and dry dock and crew travel which do have an impact by quarter. So were flat for the first quarter on a normalized basis. As Howard indicated, we were up 2% to 3% for the second quarter. We were expecting the third quarter to be up and the fourth quarter to be down and that's how we got flat to up 1% for the year. Again, it is lots of seasonal differences between the quarters.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011

componenttext: This information that we pulled together here in Miami is the result from 10 different companies giving us their estimates on what they're costs are going to be invariably. Sometimes there are variances in terms of how it actually turns out in the past. And sometimes, it's conservative. They tend to be if anything more on the conservative side and making sure that they cover the cost so we'll see what happens there.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011

componenttext: And I think and David said this many times, costs can't be judged on a quarter-to-quarter basis. It's really because of timing differences and other things, it really, you really have to look at it longer term, annual basis clearly that isn't quarter-to-quarter.

Am I understanding that correctly or is the supply shop?

And that disruption caused us some the duration in yield for the second quarter maybe I'll one point of yield for the company. componenttext: Rachel, let me just say this. We do the best route we can try to forecast. But it could be wrong, sure.

componenttext: We expect, this is Howard. We expect a strong yield improvement and based on everything we see right now and what I commented on is that we still have a way to go in the booking pattern. It's still early in the booking pattern but the pricing is strong on both for North America and Europe right now for the fourth quarter. And probably, we are hopeful we'll see similar yield improvement in the fourth quarter. That's really it. Even if you look out beyond 2011 and we have really early booking data and not all being sold in the cruise are sold, if you look at Q1 2011, '12, the booking data is encouraging as well from pricing a standpoint.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you can talk all bit about your pricing model maybe in relation to fuel? It's just an observation that fuel historically wasn't much of an issue for your industry. It's clearly a much more material component now for cost base and it
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you can talk all bit about your pricing model maybe in relation to fuel? It's just an observation that fuel historically wasn't much of an issue for your industry. It's clearly a much more material component now for cost base and it doesn't seem to be recovering despite price increases. So the question as an industry leather, have you considered adopting a maybe more aggressive pricing strategy to meet the fuel prices like may be what the airlines doe or maybe not pricing at actually?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: We price to maximize revenue and maximize profitability and not based on the price of fuel on any given day. So while obviously fuel is an issue, we have to play based on demand. And that's what we do, we try to maximize yields. To go back to the prior qu
componenttext: We price to maximize revenue and maximize profitability and not based on the price of fuel on any given day. So while obviously fuel is an issue, we have to play based on demand. And that's what we do, we try to maximize yields. To go back to the prior question, Caribbean pricing is strong in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Maybe to tight from that current set to have. And then on the fuel supplement question, you do have some fuel supplements as you said before in the U.K. and in Germany. headline: Carnival Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2011
componenttextpreview: The laws and regulation in every country is different. Our brands individually make decisions based on geographical locations and based on the laws that are in those locations. As we said, we have some brands in some countries doing fuel supplements. If w
componenttext: The laws and regulation in every country is different. Our brands individually make decisions based on geographical locations and based on the laws that are in those locations. As we said, we have some brands in some countries doing fuel supplements. If we're not doing them it's because either the brand has decided either not to do them or they can't do them because of those laws or regulations. And rather than try to go country-by-country, just leave it at that. It's a very complicated set of issues. Some countries the way, it's absolutely legal. Some countries, it depends on the price of the given time versus the type of pricing credit on the brochure et cetera, et cetera. So I'll just leave it that we're doing whatever we can to maximize revenue wherever we can.

componenttext: In general, onboard spend is up across the board and all the brand. It really hasn't been significant changes in the different marketplace by category. Most of the categories are up. We're still struggling a little bit in the casino and art, which is something we talked about over the last couple of years. But all the brands are up and I don't, there aren't any discernible difference by brand or by region.
