headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for standing by, and welcome to the Carnival Corp. Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is recorded on Tuesday, September 20, 2011. It's now my pleasure to
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for standing by, and welcome to the Carnival Corp. Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is recorded on Tuesday, September 20, 2011. It's now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Howard Frank, Vice Chairman and Chief Operating Officer at Carnival Corp. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam, and good morning, everyone or good afternoon, depending on where you are. This is Howard Frank. I'm here with Ricky Harrison, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; David Bernstein, our Senior VP of Finance and Chief Financial Officer;
componenttext: Thank you, Pam, and good morning, everyone or good afternoon, depending on where you are. This is Howard Frank. I'm here with Ricky Harrison, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; David Bernstein, our Senior VP of Finance and Chief Financial Officer; and Beth Roberts, our VP of Investor Relations. I will -- I'm going to turn the first part of the commentary over to David Bernstein who will provide you color on the third quarter on our cost outlook for the fourth quarter. David?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Before I begin, please note that as some of our remarks in this conference call will be forward-looking, I will refer to you the cautionary statements in today's press release. Also all of my references to revenue and cost metrics will
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Before I begin, please note that as some of our remarks in this conference call will be forward-looking, I will refer to you the cautionary statements in today's press release. Also all of my references to revenue and cost metrics will be in local currency unless otherwise noted, as this is a much better indicator of business trends. 
Our EPS for the third quarter was $1.69. The third quarter came in $0.07 above the midpoint of our June guidance. The $0.07 per share improvement was driven by both net revenue yield and cost as each were $0.05 better than expected. The total operational improvement of $0.10 was partially offset by a $0.02 charge related to the sale of Costa Marina, which leaves the fleet in November 2011 and $0.01 from fuel prices and currency exchange rates combined. 
The $0.05 net revenue yield improvement resulted from better-than-expected last-minute pricing. In our June guidance, we slightly overestimated the negative impact from the conflict in the Middle East and North Africa, commonly referred to as MENA, on our strong summer season. However, we believe we slightly underestimated the impact of MENA on the seasonally weaker fourth quarter. So only $0.02 of the $0.05 improvement in net revenue yields for the third quarter flows through to the full year September guidance. In total, for the back half of the year, yields are expected to be slightly better than our June guidance. 
On the cost side, a portion of the $0.05 improvement from June guidance was due to timing so only $0.03 of the $0.05 improvement in costs for the third quarter flows through to the full year September guidance. 
Now let's take a look at our third quarter operating results versus the prior year. Our capacity increased 5%, with the majority of the increase coming from our European, Australian and Asian brands, or as we call them, our EAA brands. Our EAA brands grew 7% while our North American brands grew 3%. 
Our net revenue yields increased almost 3% in the third quarter, with similar increases in both net ticket and net onboard and other yields. With respect to net ticket yield, the North American brands were up almost 6% despite the negative impact from MENA on European itineraries. The improvement was driven by higher yield in Alaska, Caribbean and Mexico Riviera itineraries. 
Our EAA brands, which are primarily cruising in Europe during the third quarter, were down 2%. The yield decline was primarily driven by the impact of MENA on these itineraries. 
In net onboard and other yields, we experienced over a 2% increase. The increase was also driven by our North American brands as our EAA brands were impacted from MENA itinerary changes that resulted in lower short excursion revenues and slightly lower spending in other areas. 
On the cost side, net cruise costs, excluding the Costa Marina charge and fuel per available lower berth day were up 2% versus the prior year. We continue to see inflationary pressures in food costs, freight, crew travel and other hotel costs that were anticipated and discussed on the last 2 conference calls. As a result of our ongoing efforts to reduce fuel usage, our consumption per available lower berth day declined 4% this quarter, continuing a multiyear savings trend. In total, this represents a 13% savings from 2007. 
Fuel prices this quarter were 45% higher than last year, which cost us $0.23 per share. Partially offsetting the increase in fuel price was the weaker dollar which had a favorable impact of $0.10 per share. In summary, the third quarter EPS improved over 4% to $1.69 per share.
Before turning to our 2011 outlook, I want to update you on our current stock repurchase program. As we previously indicated, stock buybacks could be used opportunistically to efficiently return cash to shareholders. In mid-August, we restarted our stock buyback program. Since then, we repurchased 14.5 million shares at an average price of $31 for a total of $445 million. At the present time, we have $343 million remaining on the existing general stock repurchase authorization program.  It should be noted that on a combined basis, the recent share repurchases and our 2011 full year paid dividend represents 135% of forecasted free cash flow for the year. 
Now turning to the 2011 outlook for the full year. I'll skip net revenue yields as Howard will discuss that shortly. On the cost side, for the full year, net cruise costs excluding fuel, are forecasted to be up 1%, which is the same as our June guidance excluding the charge related to the Costa Marina. At this point, I'll turn the call back over to Howard.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. My comments this morning will focus on our revenue yield outlook for the first half of 2012 since the fourth quarter of 2011 revenue picture is largely baked right now. Later in my report, I will separately comment on fourth quarter reve
componenttext:
Thank you, David. My comments this morning will focus on our revenue yield outlook for the first half of 2012 since the fourth quarter of 2011 revenue picture is largely baked right now. Later in my report, I will separately comment on fourth quarter revenue yields. 
For the first half of 2012, fleet-wide capacity will increase approximately 4.6%. Pricing per bookings taken to date for the first and second quarter are nicely higher than a year ago, with occupancy flat in the first quarter and lower in the second quarter versus the same quarters in 2011. 
For the first half of 2012, North American brand pricing increased or stronger than EAA pricing but both markets show nicely higher pricing at this time. On a fleet-wide basis, our bookings taken during the last 13 weeks for the first half of 2012 are higher year-over-year at higher pricing. Booking volumes and pricing are higher for both North America and EAA brands. While pricing during the earlier part of the 13-week period had been strong in more recent weeks, we have seen a modest falloff in bookings and pricing. This began in August largely as a result of the debt ceiling political circus in Washington and the related meltdown in the U.S. equity markets during the month. 
In Europe, the sovereign debt issues and the related concerns about the strength of the European banks contributed to the slowdown in EAA book brand bookings. These issues together which related declines in consumer confidence in the various markets in which we operate seem to have contributed to the softened booking activity during this August and early September period. 
Although fleet-wide bookings during the last 6-week period covering the next 3 quarters were not as strong as earlier in the quarter, on an absolute basis, volumes for the 6-week period were higher year-over-year with pricing on these bookings slightly lower than a year ago. So even during this difficult August and September period, bookings have held up quite well, which is a testament to the resiliency of our Cruise business and that even in a weak economic environment, the consumer will continue to book their vacations especially the value-based cruise vacations. 
Given the high percentage of business already booked in quarter one of 2012, it does appear that first quarter 2012 yields will be higher than a year ago. I will provide more specific information on our book business by quarter later in my comments. 
For the full year, we are now guiding earnings to a range of $2.40 to $2.44 a share or a midpoint of $2.42. This is a slight change from previous guidance and results from currency and fuel working against us by approximately $0.06 a share, a loss on the sales of ship by $0.02 a share that David referred to. This $0.08 combining the $0.06 and the $0.02 to get to $0.08 earnings per share negative impact is offset by improved revenue pricing of a couple of pennies a share and reduced costs of $0.03 a share. 
2012, we have 3 ships scheduled for delivery: the Costa Fascinosa in April; the AIDAmar in May and the Carnival Breeze in May. Fleet-wide capacity is expected to increase by 4.5% in 2012, 3.5% for North America brands and 6% for EAA brands. By quarter, Q1 2012 capacity is up 4.9%; second quarter 2012 is up 4.2%; third and fourth quarter of 2012 are up each by 4.4%. 
Now some color on each of the next 3 quarters. Turning to this fourth quarter that we're in right now the fourth quarter of 2011, on a fleet-wide basis, capacity is up 5.8%; 3.2% for our North America brands and 10.10% for EAA brands. Local currency pricing on a fleet-wide basis for the fourth quarter is higher year-over-year, with occupancies at a slightly lower level than last year. 
Our North American brands, we have very limited to sell at this point but for EAA brands, we still have some amount of inventory left to sell. This is primarily related to Mediterranean Cruise itineraries, which -- many of which have to be changed over the summer as a result of the problems in the Middle East and North Africa, as we've told you in the past. 
North American brands are 42% in the Caribbean in the fourth quarter, down from 50% last year, 14% in Europe versus 9% last year and 10% in the Orient Pacific area, about the same as last year. The balance is in various other itineraries. North American brand occupancies in the fourth quarter are at approximately the same levels as last year. North American brand pricing is nicely higher than a year ago, and booking volumes for North America brands in the fourth quarter continues to be solid at higher year-over-year prices. By the time the fourth quarter closes, we expect North American brand pricing to be nicely higher. 
EAA brands are 71% in Europe versus 64% last year, with the balance in various other itineraries. EAA occupancies are lower than a year ago, primarily attributable to the changed itineraries for our Med Cruises. Although occupancies for Med Cruises have caught up significantly, they are still behind last year. 
Pricing for EAA brands itineraries are behind last year, primarily attributable to the late booking of the Med Cruises. By the time the quarter ends, we expect local currency EAA pricing to be lower than a year ago. 
On a fleet-wide basis for the fourth quarter, we are forecasting higher local-currency revenue yields in the 1% to 2% range, driven by the stronger pricing for the North American brands, offset by the lower pricing for the EAA brands. 
Now turning to first quarter of 2012. As I indicated, capacity is 4.9% higher than last year, 4.5% for North America brands, 5.7% for EAA brands. At the present time, first quarter occupancies on a fleet-wide basis are approximately flat with pricing nicely higher. North American brands in the first quarter are 66% in the Caribbean, approximately the same as last year, with the balance in various other itineraries. 
The Caribbean pricing is nicely higher than a year ago on approximately the same occupancies as last year. Pricing for all other itineraries taken together in the first quarter is also higher than a year ago, also on approximately the same occupancies. 
EAA brands are 22% in the Caribbean versus 20% a year ago, 19% in Europe, down from 33% last year, 18% in South America, up slightly from 16% last year, with the balance in other itineraries. For all EAA itineraries taken together, local currency pricing is higher than a year ago at approximately the same year-over-year occupancies. 
With a good percentage of our bookings for the first quarter done as I previously mentioned, we are forecasting that revenue yield for the quarter will be higher than a year ago. 
Now turning to the second quarter of 2012. Fleet-wide capacity is up 4.2%, 2.9% for North America brands and 6.3% for EAA brands. At the present time, on a fleet-wide basis, local currency pricing is nicely higher than a year ago, with occupancies running behind last year. While the second quarter booking picture is encouraging from a pricing standpoint, it's still early in the booking cycle so I caution not to read too much into the second quarter booking picture at this time. 
North American brands are 56% in the Caribbean, approximately the same levels as last year, with the balance in various other itineraries. Caribbean pricing is nicely higher than a year ago at slightly lower occupancies. All other itineraries taken together are also nicely higher than a year ago, also at lower occupancies. 
EAA brands are 53% in Europe, down from 55% last year, with the balance in various other markets. EAA brand pricing for European cruises is higher than last year on slightly lower occupancies. Pricing for all other EAA brand itineraries taken together is also higher than a year ago at lower occupancies. 
Although occupancies in the second quarter are lower than a year ago, they are not significantly behind. And talking to our brand executives, there is a general view that because of the continuing stream of negative economic news and the related decline and more recently related decline in consumer confidence, consumer they're delaying their decisions to take their cruise vacations, with the result of the booking curve for 2012 has come closer in. 
So that's sort of the status of the second quarter where we're seeing the closer in, the bookings are taking effect. And with that, Pam, I will turn it back over to you, and we'll start to take some questions. Thank you.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Sir, our first question comes from the line Felicia Hendrix from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Sir, our first question comes from the line Felicia Hendrix from Barclays Capital.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: So Howard, you have given us some good color as usual, and you've also given us some caution on just the recent booking picture, given everything that's going on in the world and starting in August. A few things. One is do you have -- what is your confide
componenttext: So Howard, you have given us some good color as usual, and you've also given us some caution on just the recent booking picture, given everything that's going on in the world and starting in August. A few things. One is do you have -- what is your confidence that your outlook for the first quarter remains stable? I know that you said it's largely booked but those last-minute bookings always kind of affect things. And then for the second quarter, do you -- what is your optimism that you can end with pricing and occupancy up?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the first quarter, I think and I think we saw this in the fourth -- on the third quarter of 2011, our late bookings seem to be holding up quite well versus the year-ago pricing, so I think we feel fairly confident on where we stand on Q1, where it exac
componenttext: On the first quarter, I think and I think we saw this in the fourth -- on the third quarter of 2011, our late bookings seem to be holding up quite well versus the year-ago pricing, so I think we feel fairly confident on where we stand on Q1, where it exactly comes in from a yield improvement standpoint. It's -- I don't think we want to venture right now. But we are nicely ahead by now from a pricing standpoint so even with a little bit of a downdraft, we should be just fine in the first quarter. I think less so confidence in the second quarter simply because we just -- we don't have as large a percentage of our business booked in the second quarter as we have in the first quarter naturally. And we have seen, starting to see some evidence of the booking curve coming in. I think consumers are delaying their vacation decisions. It seems clear, any major spend decisions because of lower consumer confidence, seems to be -- people are pulling back on it but at the end of the day and talking to our brand managers, they seem to be pretty confident that the business will be there at the end of the day, and so I think they're more confidence in holding price.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Felicia, one of the things you have to keep in mind is that when we talk year-over-year, this time last year, bookings were very, very strong. We didn't feel the impact of MENA and all that stuff until starting in January first quarter of last year. So th
componenttext: Felicia, one of the things you have to keep in mind is that when we talk year-over-year, this time last year, bookings were very, very strong. We didn't feel the impact of MENA and all that stuff until starting in January first quarter of last year. So the fact that we're okay versus last year is patterned now. If we don't have a repeat of the MENA situation or similar or tsunami in Japan and all that other stuff, then the comparison should get easier as we get into the second quarter. So our level of confidence, all things being equal, if there isn't another major geopolitical event, should be pretty good.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: All right, okay. And then Howard, can you just tell us -- you've talked -- you said a few times that the booking curve has come in. Can you just quantify that? And then I'm wondering if someone could just tell us how the company is deployed in the Med for
componenttext: All right, okay. And then Howard, can you just tell us -- you've talked -- you said a few times that the booking curve has come in. Can you just quantify that? And then I'm wondering if someone could just tell us how the company is deployed in the Med for the summer '12 season?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean it's coming only a small amount so far. Remember, when I talk about booking curve, I'm talking about 9 different brands so. And when I give you that data, I'm looking at 9 different brands and their booking curves. Some are better than others
componenttext: Yes. I mean it's coming only a small amount so far. Remember, when I talk about booking curve, I'm talking about 9 different brands so. And when I give you that data, I'm looking at 9 different brands and their booking curves. Some are better than others but we start to see some evidence especially to some degree in the U.S. market, a little bit in the European markets and the U.K. markets.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's hard to tell because of the MENA impact but it appeared to have started to move in a little bit in the spring so it's not recent, it's not the last 6 weeks. I mean, it started to move in after the MENA impact.  And of course, when you got that many i
componenttext: It's hard to tell because of the MENA impact but it appeared to have started to move in a little bit in the spring so it's not recent, it's not the last 6 weeks. I mean, it started to move in after the MENA impact.  And of course, when you got that many itineraries moving, it becomes really hard to see what's exactly happening. But it's moved a little bit in and it seems to have started sometime in the spring.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: As to your second question, I don't have the Med broken out from Europe but I do have Europe and the Med combined. It's about 49%, 50% for 2012. It was very virtually the same in total for 2011, it was 49%.
componenttext: As to your second question, I don't have the Med broken out from Europe but I do have Europe and the Med combined. It's about 49%, 50% for 2012. It was very virtually the same in total for 2011, it was 49%.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, she said summer third quarter.
componenttext: No, she said summer third quarter.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that we have modified especially Costa which was most impacted by the MENA impact and Ibero, and to some degree, AIDA. They've already, particularly costs, have already modified a lot of itineraries to mitigate any possible future problems nex
componenttext: I would say that we have modified especially Costa which was most impacted by the MENA impact and Ibero, and to some degree, AIDA. They've already, particularly costs, have already modified a lot of itineraries to mitigate any possible future problems next year. That's not to say that we don't have any of those countries on our itineraries. We do have some but we scaled back quite a bit and have less -- quite a bit less than we have this time last year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think it's important to keep in mind that we know what we're confronting going into our European itineraries in the Med this coming year at this point in time. So I think our ability to react quicker now rather than as we reacted later in the spring
componenttext: And I think it's important to keep in mind that we know what we're confronting going into our European itineraries in the Med this coming year at this point in time. So I think our ability to react quicker now rather than as we reacted later in the spring of last year will give us the ability to mitigate the effects if there are any effects.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'd have the react -- we do have to react with a lot fewer itineraries impacted.
componenttext: We'd have the react -- we do have to react with a lot fewer itineraries impacted.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Steve Kent from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Steve Kent from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: 2 questions. First, and maybe Micky can handle this one. On the free cash flow story, it looks to me like you're going to generate about $2 billion in free cash flow next year. You've kept supply in check. So could you talk about how the board is thinking
componenttext: 2 questions. First, and maybe Micky can handle this one. On the free cash flow story, it looks to me like you're going to generate about $2 billion in free cash flow next year. You've kept supply in check. So could you talk about how the board is thinking about a dividend increase? And the reason why I think it's important at this point is that it would signal both that you're returning cash and shareholders in a very efficient way besides the share buyback, and that you're going to keep your supply growth in check. And then second, Howard, can you just define for me, just because I haven't heard it in a while what nicely really means? Has that definition changed over time, so is now nicely up 1% to 2% versus a few years ago, where it was up 3% to 4%? If you could just give us a general sense of what nicely means, that might be helpful.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe Micky answer nicely too.
componenttext: Maybe Micky answer nicely too.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Steve, I'll go through your question on the cash flow and the dividends. Essentially, we have been very open about our dividend policy. We've talked about a 30% to 40% payout on the regular quarterly dividend. Right now, we're at $1 a share. I mean, you c
componenttext: Steve, I'll go through your question on the cash flow and the dividends. Essentially, we have been very open about our dividend policy. We've talked about a 30% to 40% payout on the regular quarterly dividend. Right now, we're at $1 a share. I mean, you can do the math and you can see where the numbers are. We are committed to the 2 to 3 ships a year, and we are -- the board is, we've talked to the board and we are committed to returning all of the excess, all of the free cash flow over and above the CapEx to shareholders. As you can see, this year, we returned 135% already with the stock repurchases. So I think the commitment for the reduced capacity is there. We talked about the 2 to 3 ships, and there's not much -- for '12 and '13, those numbers are locked in and you know what's on order for the future years at this point.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, Steve, I'm going to try nicely on you. The way I -- when I look at the numbers, to me, when we talk about flattish, I usually means flat between plus or minus 1%. When I say up, it means better than 1%. But I mean, in not just 1.2% though. And when
componenttext: Okay, Steve, I'm going to try nicely on you. The way I -- when I look at the numbers, to me, when we talk about flattish, I usually means flat between plus or minus 1%. When I say up, it means better than 1%. But I mean, in not just 1.2% though. And when I say nicely up, it means well north of just being up. So without quantifying it for you, I'm getting a lot of applause here but it is means -- it means it's a stronger pricing improvement then you would just than saying that.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: So Howard, if you are just -- so have you ever said like, "Holy cow, things are really good. Is that like up 10%? I mean -- Okay. That was helpful, and David, I appreciate your answer.
componenttext: So Howard, if you are just -- so have you ever said like, "Holy cow, things are really good. Is that like up 10%? I mean -- Okay. That was helpful, and David, I appreciate your answer.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: David's answer. You asked me the question but the key underlying item in that question, I think, is discipline on the new building side and the answer to that is yes, we will.
componenttext: David's answer. You asked me the question but the key underlying item in that question, I think, is discipline on the new building side and the answer to that is yes, we will.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Robin Farley of UBS.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Robin Farley of UBS.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll ask 2 questions. One is I just wanted to circle back to the idea of the ports that you'd be revisiting 2012 in the Middle East and North Africa. I don't know if you quantified, this past year, it was originally, I think, 7% to 8% of your itineraries.
componenttext: I'll ask 2 questions. One is I just wanted to circle back to the idea of the ports that you'd be revisiting 2012 in the Middle East and North Africa. I don't know if you quantified, this past year, it was originally, I think, 7% to 8% of your itineraries. But for 2012 at this point, what percent of your itineraries would be touching those, any of those ports again?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Why don't we do this? Why don't we -- we'll see if we can pull that together for you because I don't think -- they don't have it in their books.
componenttext: Why don't we do this? Why don't we -- we'll see if we can pull that together for you because I don't think -- they don't have it in their books.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It was about -- it was 9.5% of this year's itineraries were impacted.  And I believe, if I remember correctly, we did analysis. We reduced their exposure by about 12%. So there was a reduction in the number of itineraries that went to the affected regions
componenttext: It was about -- it was 9.5% of this year's itineraries were impacted.  And I believe, if I remember correctly, we did analysis. We reduced their exposure by about 12%. So there was a reduction in the number of itineraries that went to the affected regions. Costa replaced some of -- replaced Tunisia with some islands off the coast of Italy. They took ships out of Egypt and went to the Greek Isles and the Holy Land. So there were a number of changes that resulted in that 12% reduction.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I could say Costa basically reworked their entire 2012 Med program and rereleased their program a couple of weeks ago. So it's not that easy to say because rather than have itineraries overlapping, they kind of took a fresh piece of paper approach and hav
componenttext: I could say Costa basically reworked their entire 2012 Med program and rereleased their program a couple of weeks ago. So it's not that easy to say because rather than have itineraries overlapping, they kind of took a fresh piece of paper approach and have a lot of new programs that they're feeling very, very excited about when in reality, when they have to react last-minute, they really couldn't -- they couldn't look at it in the same way. So I think they've taken a fresh approach. They've basically done the kind of itineraries that their nationality of passenger will really enjoy. And those nationalities were most impacted, Italian, French, Spanish by the MENA issues. So I don't think we can quantify at this point. Maybe Beth?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: But the 8.5% will be at ports of call that were not as challenged, let's say, as they were last year like Egypt and Tunisia.
componenttext: But the 8.5% will be at ports of call that were not as challenged, let's say, as they were last year like Egypt and Tunisia.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Now just still going down to the buying and selling in places like that, those cruises are doing okay.
componenttext: Now just still going down to the buying and selling in places like that, those cruises are doing okay.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, they still have cruises in to buy but less capacity, they got big capacity.
componenttext: Yes, they still have cruises in to buy but less capacity, they got big capacity.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Now that's helpful. And then the second question is, can you just remind us for your ship whether those are outstanding, just kind of which are financing in place and which would be in the process in terms of anything that was guaranteed expo
componenttext: Okay, great. Now that's helpful. And then the second question is, can you just remind us for your ship whether those are outstanding, just kind of which are financing in place and which would be in the process in terms of anything that was guaranteed export credit facilities in the contracts, just in light of a lot of change going on with European banks just over.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. We've got 10 ships in order. The only one that does not have financing associated with it is the Costa Favolosa for 2012 -- Fascinosa, sorry, for 2012. The other 9, 7 are already signed and done, and we're working on the last 2. So we will have
componenttext: Sure, yes. We've got 10 ships in order. The only one that does not have financing associated with it is the Costa Favolosa for 2012 -- Fascinosa, sorry, for 2012. The other 9, 7 are already signed and done, and we're working on the last 2. So we will have export credits for the other 9. We just haven't finished the last 2 with the AIDA ships that we ordered in Germany.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so and I'm sorry, you said the Fascinosa for next year, that the financing is done for that?
componenttext: Okay. And so and I'm sorry, you said the Fascinosa for next year, that the financing is done for that?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. No that's the only ship.
componenttext: No. No that's the only ship.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's the 1 out of 9 that we didn't lock in export credit. It's complicated but export credits for the Italian shipyard, for Italian flagship is not -- it's complicated. So we passed on that one because it's not an export. We've taken an export credit. We'
componenttext: It's the 1 out of 9 that we didn't lock in export credit. It's complicated but export credits for the Italian shipyard, for Italian flagship is not -- it's complicated. So we passed on that one because it's not an export. We've taken an export credit. We're not exporting.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Janet Brashear of Sanford C. Bernstein.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Janet Brashear of Sanford C. Bernstein.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a little bit about discounting for 2012. Some travel agents have said that they feel that the discounting for all of 2012 feels stronger than they might have expected. As you look at your pricing, I know you said earlier that the brand man
componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit about discounting for 2012. Some travel agents have said that they feel that the discounting for all of 2012 feels stronger than they might have expected. As you look at your pricing, I know you said earlier that the brand managers are trying to hold price, believing that consumer confidence may still rebound. Are you feeling like the discounting environment is normal for this time as pre-bookings for 2012?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think if there are a lot of sales going on and programs going on. Most of that, Janet, would be for more closer in business as a plus. And some of it is not dissimilar to what we've done in prior years. So when the travel agents see it, I'm not sure the
componenttext: I think if there are a lot of sales going on and programs going on. Most of that, Janet, would be for more closer in business as a plus. And some of it is not dissimilar to what we've done in prior years. So when the travel agents see it, I'm not sure they see it in the same way we see it in terms of our yield management systems and what we need to do to get it done. And in many cases, we do go out with different kinds of programs, and they may -- we may do them in a little bit different ways than we've done in past years so they don't have the ability to really understand from the apples-to-apples comparisons that we work with in terms of our pricing. But yes, it is out there, it is out there, sure. It's always out there, though.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, a quick question too. You had talked about a fuel cost protection program. I won't say hedging because I think you were doing something different with just protecting at the extreme cost swing levels. Is that progressing?
componenttext: Okay, a quick question too. You had talked about a fuel cost protection program. I won't say hedging because I think you were doing something different with just protecting at the extreme cost swing levels. Is that progressing?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're working on off the administrative back-office that we put in place, and the systems controls and procedures. But we haven't started doing anything yet, and that's at some point in the near future and when we start, we'll let everybody know.
componenttext: Yes. We're working on off the administrative back-office that we put in place, and the systems controls and procedures. But we haven't started doing anything yet, and that's at some point in the near future and when we start, we'll let everybody know.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Harry Curtis from Nomura Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. The first is you've mentioned that in 2011, you'll be returning about 145% of your expected free cash flow to shareholders. To what degree would you be willing to use your balance sheet over a longer-term period to repurchase
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. The first is you've mentioned that in 2011, you'll be returning about 145% of your expected free cash flow to shareholders. To what degree would you be willing to use your balance sheet over a longer-term period to repurchase stock?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think generally speaking, we've talked about returning free cash flow, I think in this particular year where there was an opportunity to buy back stock at a quite attractive price, and we had the program already in place to do it. We decided to go ahead
componenttext: I think generally speaking, we've talked about returning free cash flow, I think in this particular year where there was an opportunity to buy back stock at a quite attractive price, and we had the program already in place to do it. We decided to go ahead and do it to running a little bit faster than free cash flow for 2011. So I think over the long haul, I think that the thinking is that debt levels would remain relatively constant and would use free cash flow to buy back stock and/or increase dividends.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if you could just give us or remind us rather the range of net-debt-to-EBITDA that you feel comfortable with?
componenttext: And if you could just give us or remind us rather the range of net-debt-to-EBITDA that you feel comfortable with?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we're really looking at in terms of -- we look at it more in terms of ratings. And what we're looking at is an A- credit rating is what we're generally targeting as opposed to a net-debt-to-EBITDA. Although if you look at the S&P, A- will equate to s
componenttext: What we're really looking at in terms of -- we look at it more in terms of ratings. And what we're looking at is an A- credit rating is what we're generally targeting as opposed to a net-debt-to-EBITDA. Although if you look at the S&P, A- will equate to somewhere between 2x and 2.5x, roughly speaking.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. And then just a bigger picture question, and it's really a philosophical industry question. The airline industry over the past few years has taken 10% to 15% of their capacity out, and they've enjoyed a relatively strong increase in pr
componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then just a bigger picture question, and it's really a philosophical industry question. The airline industry over the past few years has taken 10% to 15% of their capacity out, and they've enjoyed a relatively strong increase in pricing power. And next year, the cruise industry is still going to see about a 4% increase in capacity.  And I'm just wondering if you thought about the positive impact that you might see on pricing if the industry itself reduced capacity? And by the same token, what would be the argument against it?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The challenge to reduce capacity, although we do, over time, we do try to sell off some of our older tonnage if we can get reasonable prizes for them. But it's unlike the airline industry, it's not easy to get -- to move out your older ships. Also newer s
componenttext: The challenge to reduce capacity, although we do, over time, we do try to sell off some of our older tonnage if we can get reasonable prizes for them. But it's unlike the airline industry, it's not easy to get -- to move out your older ships. Also newer ships give us so much better economies of scale that we're inclined to order newer ships, larger ships that give us the scale benefits and returns that we can't get on the older tonnage. But over time, we will move out over time. Will we ever get to a flat or down capacity year-over-year from a cruise industry standpoint? I don't know. I mean, I don't -- we still see huge potential to grow our business in certain markets, and I think when we order ships today, we're ordering it for those markets where we believe we can continue to grow our capacity at good profit improvement and improved return on invested capital. So it is a much more targeted approach. There could come a time that when we stop ordering ships. And for certain markets, we've done that but not for other markets. So I think it is a much targeted approach. I hope that answers your questions, Harry.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011

componenttext: We're going to continue on. Our next question comes from the line of Tim Conder, Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011

componenttext: Howard, could you give us a little bit more detailed color on how things are printed on a regional booking basis, particularly for European sourced passenger since that August period? I guess for the Northern European or western itineraries looking into the first half of next year versus the Southern European itineraries?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't -- to be honest with you, Tim, I don't have that information. All I looked at it was from Europe.
componenttext: I don't -- to be honest with you, Tim, I don't have that information. All I looked at it was from Europe.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The European, you're talking for next summer?
componenttext: The European, you're talking for next summer?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011

componenttext: Yes. It's way too early for places like Italy, France and Spain. I mean, Costa just issued their advisable 2 weeks ago, and they just started taking bookings so it's way too early for those countries to be commenting on next year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Northern Europe tends to be a much shorter season starting later and ending earlier so they're not comparable between Europe and Northern Europe and the Med. Med will start to go out a little bit earlier.
componenttext: And Northern Europe tends to be a much shorter season starting later and ending earlier so they're not comparable between Europe and Northern Europe and the Med. Med will start to go out a little bit earlier.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess the root of the question is you haven't seen any major shifts since prior to the beginning of August in the patterns of bookings for Northern Europeans versus Southern Europeans?
componenttext: Okay. So I guess the root of the question is you haven't seen any major shifts since prior to the beginning of August in the patterns of bookings for Northern Europeans versus Southern Europeans?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I haven't looked at it from that standpoint, to be honest with you. I just -- I'm just looking at -- it's tough enough to take 9 different businesses, put it all together and come up with an answer directionally that makes sense. But to start to analyze i
componenttext: I haven't looked at it from that standpoint, to be honest with you. I just -- I'm just looking at -- it's tough enough to take 9 different businesses, put it all together and come up with an answer directionally that makes sense. But to start to analyze it itinerary by itinerary, by business by business and to give it to you, it wouldn't make a lot of sense and it would take a long time to do that, and it's just not possible to try to take all the information, pull it together and do it in a way that gives you proper and the direction in terms of how the business overall is going.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that for the European brands, clearly, they've had very strong last-minute bookings, which is a combination of things, I think, it's economy but I think it's also the fact, because of MENA, there was more availability last minute that there we
componenttext: I would say that for the European brands, clearly, they've had very strong last-minute bookings, which is a combination of things, I think, it's economy but I think it's also the fact, because of MENA, there was more availability last minute that there were in prior years because of the, I call it, itinerary changes. And they've failed so and when you look at the bottom line for the third quarter, they were down 2 points, which considering everything that happened this year, that's not a terrible result.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, now a very fair answer. And then what, at this point, as you see the world and based on what the brand managers are telling you, what are you looking at as far as in FY '12, the recovery out of what was triggered through the tsunami impact and the e
componenttext: Okay, now a very fair answer. And then what, at this point, as you see the world and based on what the brand managers are telling you, what are you looking at as far as in FY '12, the recovery out of what was triggered through the tsunami impact and the earthquakes in Asia? And then relative to are you looking for any recovery from the MENA area in particular? And then I guess the other part would be, you cited the U.K. as being a little tepid if I interpreted your remarks correctly. How are you looking at that year-over-year from -- as you see the world today and what the brand managers are flowing up?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, what the brand managers are telling me is really more anecdotal based on what's happened in the last 4 or 6 weeks or so, so I wouldn't want to give you an overall sense of what 2012 looks like. I do think it's too early. We are all over now in Europ
componenttext: Well, what the brand managers are telling me is really more anecdotal based on what's happened in the last 4 or 6 weeks or so, so I wouldn't want to give you an overall sense of what 2012 looks like. I do think it's too early. We are all over now in Europe and starting our meetings with the brand managers on reviewing 2012 budgets later on. In September, early October, we'll be doing the same with our U.S. brands.  And so I'm always a little bit uncomfortable right now, given the fact that it's September talking too much about 2012 because I don't think we feel comfortable doing it yet. I mean, there are a lot of very positive things out there. I talked about the yield, the positive pricing in Q1 and Q2, which we think is we're pleased with. But I think given all the noise that we're hearing in the U.S. and Europe about economic challenges, I'd like to wait until December to give you more concrete and more concrete guidance on 2012 when we have a little bit more confidence in how it's going to shape up.  And so I hesitate to give you anything right now.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Even in December, we're going to do it. It's going to be tricky because again, we're going to be looking at comparisons that didn't have any of the MENA impact yet. And again, at December last year, we were looking at a very, very strong year. And things
componenttext: Even in December, we're going to do it. It's going to be tricky because again, we're going to be looking at comparisons that didn't have any of the MENA impact yet. And again, at December last year, we were looking at a very, very strong year. And things started to come apart middle of January. So when we're sitting and looking at year-over-year comparisons, we're going to have to try what happened so it's going to make those predictions a little bit trickier than the past.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The one thing that's definitely going to be a positive is 2011 had the short-term disruption of all those itinerary changes and all those cancellations, and hopefully we won't, as Micky mentioned before, we won't see that again in 2012 and that would be a
componenttext: The one thing that's definitely going to be a positive is 2011 had the short-term disruption of all those itinerary changes and all those cancellations, and hopefully we won't, as Micky mentioned before, we won't see that again in 2012 and that would be a year-over-year positive.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And to your point, I think Micky earlier, you mentioned that given all that and you had strong bookings at this time last year, you're already, from what you're seeing right now, it's still fairly, fairly solid given that you're going to get those strong
componenttext: And to your point, I think Micky earlier, you mentioned that given all that and you had strong bookings at this time last year, you're already, from what you're seeing right now, it's still fairly, fairly solid given that you're going to get those strong comps at this point in time.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the point Howard was making, we're booking very strongly into the spring and early summer. Again, part of that was the fact that we had all the disruptions so we had a lot more capacity available closed in. The part of it was obvious, demand
componenttext: Yes, I think the point Howard was making, we're booking very strongly into the spring and early summer. Again, part of that was the fact that we had all the disruptions so we had a lot more capacity available closed in. The part of it was obvious, demand especially for the peak holiday season. But despite a slowdown in August and early September, we were up year-over-year. And that's a good sign but there's no question that people are tightening their belt a little bit and making decisions a little bit later based because of everything that's going on and what they're watching on television every day.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Kevin Milota of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Kevin Milota of JPMorgan.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just was wondering if you could give some updated thoughts on where you are from a fuel hedging perspective. Understandably, you guys don't do that now but there's been some commentary in the past that you were thinking about more of a fuel insurance goin
componenttext: Just was wondering if you could give some updated thoughts on where you are from a fuel hedging perspective. Understandably, you guys don't do that now but there's been some commentary in the past that you were thinking about more of a fuel insurance going forward. And then also from a MENA perspective, not to beat a dead horse here, but was wondering if it's possible to quantify what sort of drag pricing is going to have next year or maybe you could speak to it in terms of how long do you think it will take to get back to pre-turmoil levels in terms of pricing for those itineraries?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You want to go ahead on it?
componenttext: You want to go ahead on it?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as the fuel hedging, I mean, we've talked about our philosophy a number of times on fuel hedging. And the kind of program we're looking at is more fuel insurance.  And the example I think I've used historically could be something like a 0 cost
componenttext: Yes. As far as the fuel hedging, I mean, we've talked about our philosophy a number of times on fuel hedging. And the kind of program we're looking at is more fuel insurance.  And the example I think I've used historically could be something like a 0 cost collar with a wide collar so that if fuel did spike up, we have some protection. Those are the types of things we're looking at doing, and I mentioned before we're putting together the administrative back office to begin to do that at some point in the future.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kevin, on the MENA pricing for 2012 versus 2011, I think that certainly, we're hopeful that we'll see some nice improvement in pricing versus 2011, given that the lateness or the changes in the itinerary, the disruption, not only to the MENA Cruises
componenttext: Yes, Kevin, on the MENA pricing for 2012 versus 2011, I think that certainly, we're hopeful that we'll see some nice improvement in pricing versus 2011, given that the lateness or the changes in the itinerary, the disruption, not only to the MENA Cruises but all of our Med cruises resulting from the last-minute changes and the rebooking patterns that we had to go through. How much that will be, I think it's still too early to say. Will we recapture everything we lost? I don't think so. I don't think we're even -- we're thinking in those terms. But we do think we'll start to see some improvement but it may take us a couple of years to get back to the levels of pricing that we enjoyed pre-MENA.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to put it in perspective, I mean, we did say that the MENA impact this year in 2011 was about a 1.5 points of yield, which is kind of gives you a total perspective of the magnitude of the issue.
componenttext: Just to put it in perspective, I mean, we did say that the MENA impact this year in 2011 was about a 1.5 points of yield, which is kind of gives you a total perspective of the magnitude of the issue.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian from Citigroup.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian from Citigroup.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Jeff Hans on behalf of Greg. Can you talk a little bit about some of the tactical promotions or discounts out there today? And is that any different than sort of what you've seen during past periods of volatile bookings or has it been a bit more aggr
componenttext: It's Jeff Hans on behalf of Greg. Can you talk a little bit about some of the tactical promotions or discounts out there today? And is that any different than sort of what you've seen during past periods of volatile bookings or has it been a bit more aggressive?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've discounted sale and it's part of a marketing strategy. Again, if we're talking for 1 or 2 brands, it would be much easier to answer your question. Every one of our brands has different kind of promotions, different tactics, different sales. They hav
componenttext: We've discounted sale and it's part of a marketing strategy. Again, if we're talking for 1 or 2 brands, it would be much easier to answer your question. Every one of our brands has different kind of promotions, different tactics, different sales. They haven't, virtually every year, not necessarily at the exact same time, they all watch their booking periods. They all have trend lines and when they get below the trend line, they may activate a discount program. When they get above it, they'll pull it back and so on. So there's a lot of moving pieces and it doesn't -- other than the fact that you've got all this noise going on because of what's going on in Washington and what's going on in Wall Street, and also in Europe obviously with the financial crisis in Europe, all that noise is just making it really difficult to tell. But like we've said a number of times at the call today, our volumes are still up year-over-year. So I think it does not feel like any different than -- it definitely doesn't feel like '08 where we saw significant drop off. It doesn't feel anything like that.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's nothing like that. You don't see -- when you look at sort of springtime until now, an ebb and flow to bookings. In some weeks, they're very strong and other weeks are not as strong, and at the end of the month, we kind of look at the overall and so f
componenttext: It's nothing like that. You don't see -- when you look at sort of springtime until now, an ebb and flow to bookings. In some weeks, they're very strong and other weeks are not as strong, and at the end of the month, we kind of look at the overall and so far, it's been positive.  And remember, we can move business. So you're not quite sure if you have a strong booking month. It's because we're moving business at lower prices, and if we pull up and our booking prices are lower, it's because we may have pulled pricing up. And you're talking about 8 or 10, 8 or 9 different yield management systems, and each business approaches yield management in different ways. So it is really difficult to talk about a particular program of moving business and how it's affecting that particular business. Looking at it from -- we look at it from a global standpoint.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right. I didn't mean as much you guys. I meant just from what you're seeing out there, given the volatility over the last 4 to 6 weeks. And I mean, there's been periods of volatility obviously over the past 12-plus months. But just wondering if you've see
componenttext: Right. I didn't mean as much you guys. I meant just from what you're seeing out there, given the volatility over the last 4 to 6 weeks. And I mean, there's been periods of volatility obviously over the past 12-plus months. But just wondering if you've seen other players out there discounting a bit more aggressively than other periods of volatility or has it been just a sort of normal course of business?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You do see tactical pricing, and every once in a while, one of our -- I'll have a conversation on Micky Wheel or David Wheeler, the brand managers saying, "Our competitors are doing this at this particular price or this particular market." But it's usuall
componenttext: You do see tactical pricing, and every once in a while, one of our -- I'll have a conversation on Micky Wheel or David Wheeler, the brand managers saying, "Our competitors are doing this at this particular price or this particular market." But it's usually for a particular cruise that they need to feel.  And sometimes, we do the same thing. So you can't really go too much by the anecdotal information.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd like to say that beyond the MENA itineraries which continue to be last-minute fill because there were so many changes, beyond that, I don't think it's any different than what we saw last year.
componenttext: I'd like to say that beyond the MENA itineraries which continue to be last-minute fill because there were so many changes, beyond that, I don't think it's any different than what we saw last year.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Assia Georgieva from Infinity Research.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Assia Georgieva from Infinity Research.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I had a quick question on Q4. It seems that implied yield guidance had previously been in the 2.4% range, and now you're offering us 1% to 2%. Is this primarily due to the slower August and September booking volumes? Or is it primarily because of Costa or
componenttext: I had a quick question on Q4. It seems that implied yield guidance had previously been in the 2.4% range, and now you're offering us 1% to 2%. Is this primarily due to the slower August and September booking volumes? Or is it primarily because of Costa or a combination of the 2?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It really is primarily as a result of the seasonalization of the MENA impact. As I mentioned in my notes, we had overestimated the impact on the third quarter and underestimated the negative impact of MENA on the fourth quarter. So when everything came in
componenttext: It really is primarily as a result of the seasonalization of the MENA impact. As I mentioned in my notes, we had overestimated the impact on the third quarter and underestimated the negative impact of MENA on the fourth quarter. So when everything came in and we started to look at it, while the total impact of MENA, we were very close and we felt good about that, the yield difference is driven by those MENA itineraries. We had expected MENA to be roughly 2% in the third quarter. It turned out more like a 1.5%. And in the fourth quarter, we had expected it to be more like 0.5% -- 1.5% and it turned out to be more than 2%. So it's just a forecasting estimate on our part and a flip-flop between the quarters.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can I just say that when you consider that we changed 300 itineraries just before we gave you the second quarter guidance, the fact that we're basically right on our guidance for the second half of the year, I think it's pretty remarkable. Our folks did a
componenttext: Can I just say that when you consider that we changed 300 itineraries just before we gave you the second quarter guidance, the fact that we're basically right on our guidance for the second half of the year, I think it's pretty remarkable. Our folks did a great job of being able to forecast this far. But the fact that it's a little bit higher in one quarter, a little bit lower in another quarter, I mean, come on, you're moving 300 itineraries. It's pretty good.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I think the thing to keep in mind is that for the second half of the year, we actually came in yield wide a little bit just slightly better. But it was a flip flop between Q3 and Q4, that's what you're seeing.
componenttext: So I think the thing to keep in mind is that for the second half of the year, we actually came in yield wide a little bit just slightly better. But it was a flip flop between Q3 and Q4, that's what you're seeing.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And Micky, I think we all appreciate how difficult it is and especially for the Costa brand, what they have had to go through. By the same measure, is it possible that closing bookings might be helpful in Q4, not only in the Bahamas, in the sh
componenttext: Okay, okay. And Micky, I think we all appreciate how difficult it is and especially for the Costa brand, what they have had to go through. By the same measure, is it possible that closing bookings might be helpful in Q4, not only in the Bahamas, in the short Caribbean but also in Europe, if you still have inventory available to sell more than in past years?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're pretty well along now. But if last-minute bookings are stronger than anticipated, then we'll do a little bit better. But we're pretty well booked in the quarter.
componenttext: We're pretty well along now. But if last-minute bookings are stronger than anticipated, then we'll do a little bit better. But we're pretty well booked in the quarter.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Given stronger demand in Q3, you typically can get some upside. Q4 is a little bit more challenging. I think North America, as I mentioned, is substantially done right now. And really, what we need to do is some backfill still on the MENA sailings and tha
componenttext: Given stronger demand in Q3, you typically can get some upside. Q4 is a little bit more challenging. I think North America, as I mentioned, is substantially done right now. And really, what we need to do is some backfill still on the MENA sailings and that's really, all that's significantly left. So could it come in better than we anticipated? Sure, but not by that much room, no.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're going to continue on. Our next question comes from the line of Richard Lyall from John W. Bristol and Co.
componenttext: We're going to continue on. Our next question comes from the line of Richard Lyall from John W. Bristol and Co.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I got a couple of questions. Are you implicitly saying that the booking curve on the North American business has moved out?
componenttext: I got a couple of questions. Are you implicitly saying that the booking curve on the North American business has moved out?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. What we're saying is the booking curve on all our business has moved in a little bit.
componenttext: No. What we're saying is the booking curve on all our business has moved in a little bit.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. But given the strength in pricing and the fact that you're already booked, it's not saying that North America has moved out?
componenttext: Okay. But given the strength in pricing and the fact that you're already booked, it's not saying that North America has moved out?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. The opposite, it's moved in a little bit as well.
componenttext: No. The opposite, it's moved in a little bit as well.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is historically, when there's been uncertainty coming into a new year, you've been aggressive on pricing. And this time around, you're holding off on the pricing card and say, "We're going to stick with what we got," and play the car
componenttext: Okay. Second question is historically, when there's been uncertainty coming into a new year, you've been aggressive on pricing. And this time around, you're holding off on the pricing card and say, "We're going to stick with what we got," and play the card later in the year if you need to. Why the different philosophy?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just say this. I don't think there's any one philosophy here. There are a multitude of philosophies on yield management, and each brand manager approaches it -- can approach it very differently, and what we're giving you is a blend of all tha
componenttext: Well, let me just say this. I don't think there's any one philosophy here. There are a multitude of philosophies on yield management, and each brand manager approaches it -- can approach it very differently, and what we're giving you is a blend of all that information. So in some cases, I think some people -- some of our brands will go in with a stronger pricing early on and hope to maintain it and move whatever inventory is left at the end that's somewhat lower pricing. Other brands will go in at early at lower pricing to begin with, expect to fill and then move the volumes as they need to in order to fill up. So they're just different approaches each one will do and what we're giving you is a blend of all of them.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's been any changes in the philosophy. It's just yield management folks recognizing a movement in of the booking curve will retract the line of what they expect and want. And so they will react a little bit later than they would have in
componenttext: I don't think there's been any changes in the philosophy. It's just yield management folks recognizing a movement in of the booking curve will retract the line of what they expect and want. And so they will react a little bit later than they would have in the prior year with the booking curve further out. Did that make sense?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit riskier but you're betting that the booking curve has moved in, and there's a lot of good anecdotal evidence to prove that it has, and so you might as well play that curve rather than react too early.
componenttext: It's a little bit riskier but you're betting that the booking curve has moved in, and there's a lot of good anecdotal evidence to prove that it has, and so you might as well play that curve rather than react too early.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I understand. I just think it's interesting you're doing things differently this time. Last quick question is I think I thought Pier Foschi said that he had not changed itineraries for 2012 beyond first quarter of 2012. So what occasioned the changes
componenttext: No, I understand. I just think it's interesting you're doing things differently this time. Last quick question is I think I thought Pier Foschi said that he had not changed itineraries for 2012 beyond first quarter of 2012. So what occasioned the changes in itineraries? Did you decide that the situation could be more negative longer and you needed to deploy capacity differently?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're reacting to a conversation I know we had in July, correct?
componenttext: You're reacting to a conversation I know we had in July, correct?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I've had a conversation with him at dinner.
componenttext: No, I've had a conversation with him at dinner.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: In July?
componenttext: In July?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Whenever that was.
componenttext: Whenever that was.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: In July. This is now September. The reality is since July, we've had a number of conversations, and the question became a mitigation of risk.  And so they basically went back to the drawing board, took a clean piece of paper and said, "Okay, what is the b
componenttext: In July. This is now September. The reality is since July, we've had a number of conversations, and the question became a mitigation of risk.  And so they basically went back to the drawing board, took a clean piece of paper and said, "Okay, what is the best itineraries we can operate for our major nationalities and mitigate the MENA risk?" And that's what they did. And they come up with a whole new set of itineraries, some very, very innovative ones, I think. It's some great ideas. We're very hopeful that they'll be very successful but they have to go back to the drawing board, reprint a brand new brochure for next spring and summer. They've done that. It's now in the market place but it's only been in the market place about 2 weeks so it will take sometime to see how all that flies. But we're very glad that they did that. We think they've made a lot of good decisions and we'll see what happens 6 months from now.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Jamie Rollo from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Continuing on, our next question comes from the line of Jamie Rollo from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a first question on costs. I know you haven't done your budgets yet for next year but if we do see a bigger-than-expected downturn, how much flexibility do you have to take further cost out? I know it used to be quite a big chunk in '09 but do you th
componenttext: Just a first question on costs. I know you haven't done your budgets yet for next year but if we do see a bigger-than-expected downturn, how much flexibility do you have to take further cost out? I know it used to be quite a big chunk in '09 but do you think -- I mean, do you have a sort of backup plan if things are quite tough?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I mean, we are always looking at ways to reduce costs. We're not a business where we have a lot of fat in the business so when there's an economic downturn, we can change our model and all of a sudden take all that fat. We run very lean and we're c
componenttext: Jamie, I mean, we are always looking at ways to reduce costs. We're not a business where we have a lot of fat in the business so when there's an economic downturn, we can change our model and all of a sudden take all that fat. We run very lean and we're constantly looking for ways to reduce costs. So we're hoping we can offset the inflation next year. We've told everybody our long-term cost guidance is flat to half of inflation. Hopefully, we'll be closer to flat than half of inflation as we work to all the cost savings.

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just the other question was relating to a comments, I think, one of you made on may be selling some more ships in the future, some of the old ships. I think you've got 7 or 8 ships that are 20 years or more in age. I'm just wondering first, does
componenttext: Okay. And just the other question was relating to a comments, I think, one of you made on may be selling some more ships in the future, some of the old ships. I think you've got 7 or 8 ships that are 20 years or more in age. I'm just wondering first, does that have a meaningful impact on group net cruise costs, just given these ships are significantly less efficient than modern ships? And also, the loss you made on selling the, I know it's small but you did normally make very losses when you sell ships so are you happy with the book value of your fleet today?

headline: Carnival Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Sep 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the book value of our fleet, we're very happy. You're picking on one ship. But I did look at the last 8 ship sales. It turns out that in the last 8 ship sales, we had 4 gains and 4 losses. The total cumulative net for the 8 was a positive
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the book value of our fleet, we're very happy. You're picking on one ship. But I did look at the last 8 ship sales. It turns out that in the last 8 ship sales, we had 4 gains and 4 losses. The total cumulative net for the 8 was a positive, I think it was $45 million. So when to have it turn out to be that way, we felt very comfortable with our book value overall. As far as the cost impact of selling these older ships, I think the last time I looked, those 7 ships represented about 3% of our overall capacity because remember, the older ships tend to be smaller so even if we sold all 7 of them, I doubt you would see a dramatic change in our net cruise costs because it's just 3% of the total.
